dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Michael Bloomberg just wrote a piece on Huffington Post where he claims he could beat Hillary Clinton in a general election.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Michael Bloomberg just wrote a piece on Huffington Post where he claims he could beat Hillary Clinton in a general election.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: I believe I would defeat Donald Trump in a general election, Bloomberg wrote in an editorial posted to his eponymous news site.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, interesting—but he's not running, right? He called her a friend to the country, which is uh, pretty diplomatic for a potential rival.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, interesting-but he's not running, right? He called her a friend to the country, which is uh, pretty diplomatic for a potential rival.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the editorial, the former New York City mayor called Trump a threat to our country and emphasized the need to nominate a Democratic candidate who could beat him in the general election.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and he's putting his money where his mouth is—he plans to spend $100 million of his own money to elect Clinton.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and he's putting his money where his mouth is-he plans to spend one hundred dollars million of his own money to elect Clinton.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, he plans to spend $500 million of his own money to defeat Trump, adding to the $100 million he spent on behalf of Democrats in the 2018 midterms.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's on top of the $500 million he spent backing Republicans in 2016. The guy's influence is massive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's on top of the five hundred dollars million he spent backing Republicans in twenty sixteen. The guy's influence is massive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, he plans to spend $500 million of his own money to defeat Trump, adding to the $100 million he spent on behalf of Democrats in the 2018 midterms.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And he's worth like $12.5 billion, so he can afford to play kingmaker.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And he's worth like twelve point five dollars billion, so he can afford to play kingmaker.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bloomberg is worth an estimated $55.6 billion; he placed ninth on Forbes 2019 rankings of the Worlds Billionaires.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But it's not just about elections—he's also launching this new initiative, Beyond Oil, to move away from carbon.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it's not just about elections-he's also launching this new initiative, Beyond Oil, to move away from carbon.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In lieu of running, Bloomberg will devote the next two years to a new initiative, Beyond Carbon, a grassroots effort to begin moving America as quickly as possible away from oil and gas and toward a 100 percent clean energy economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, though his own history is a bit mixed—his company built coal plants and increased air pollution in the past.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, though his own history is a bit mixed-his company built coal plants and increased air pollution in the past.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: His foundation has already worked to shutter coal-fired power plants and reduce air pollution.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's the irony, isn't it? Now he wants to lead the charge toward cleaner energy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the irony, isn't it? Now he wants to lead the charge toward cleaner energy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In lieu of running, Bloomberg will devote the next two years to a new initiative, Beyond Carbon, a grassroots effort to begin moving America as quickly as possible away from oil and gas and toward a 100 percent clean energy economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Do you think an independent candidate, like Jeff Bezos, could actually unite Trump and Clinton voters like he suggested?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Do you think an independent candidate, like Jeff Bezos, could actually unite Trump and Clinton voters like he suggested?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In January, he obliquely criticized the possible candidacy of Howard Schultz, the billionaire founder of Starbucks, saying that the great likelihood is that an independent candidate would just split the anti-Trump vote and end up reelecting the president.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, I doubt it. Third parties usually split the vote rather than unite it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, I doubt it. Third parties usually split the vote rather than unite it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Bloomberg seems clear-eyed about the Republican primary too—he called it a crowded field, hard to win.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Bloomberg seems clear-eyed about the Republican primary too-he called it a crowded field, hard to win.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But I am clear-eyed about the difficulty of winning the Democratic nomination in such a crowded field.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. He's pragmatic. Even praised congressional Democrats for holding the president accountable.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. He's pragmatic. Even praised congressional Democrats for holding the president accountable.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bloomberg, a former Republican himself, also castigated congressional Republicans, who he says have failedand are still failingto fulfill their constitutional duty to hold the president accountable.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So his real power might be behind the scenes—funding, influencing, shaping policy through Beyond Oil.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So his real power might be behind the scenes-funding, influencing, shaping policy through Beyond Oil.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In lieu of running, Bloomberg will devote the next two years to a new initiative, Beyond Carbon, a grassroots effort to begin moving America as quickly as possible away from oil and gas and toward a 100 percent clean energy economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. He doesn't need to run when he can spend and advocate from the sidelines.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. He doesn't need to run when he can spend and advocate from the sidelines.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, he plans to spend $500 million of his own money to defeat Trump, adding to the $100 million he spent on behalf of Democrats in the 2018 midterms.

artist_script:
Carbon neutrality by 2050 is a fantasy without immediate corporate action.
HostA: Michael Bloomberg just wrote a piece on Huffington Post where he claims he could beat Hillary Clinton in a general election.
HostB: Oh, interesting—but he’s not running, right? He called her a friend to the country, which is uh, pretty diplomatic for a potential rival.
HostA: Yeah, and he’s putting his money where his mouth is—he plans to spend $100 million of his own money to elect Clinton.
HostB: That’s on top of the $500 million he spent backing Republicans in 2016. The guy’s influence is massive.
HostA: Exactly. And he’s worth like $12.5 billion, so he can afford to play kingmaker.
HostB: But it’s not just about elections—he’s also launching this new initiative, Beyond Oil, to move away from carbon.
HostA: Right, though his own history is a bit mixed—his company built coal plants and increased air pollution in the past.
HostB: That’s the irony, isn’t it? Now he wants to lead the charge toward cleaner energy.
HostA: Do you think an independent candidate, like Jeff Bezos, could actually unite Trump and Clinton voters like he suggested?
HostB: Honestly, I doubt it. Third parties usually split the vote rather than unite it.
HostA: Bloomberg seems clear-eyed about the Republican primary too—he called it a crowded field, hard to win.
HostB: For sure. He’s pragmatic. Even praised congressional Democrats for holding the president accountable.
HostA: So his real power might be behind the scenes—funding, influencing, shaping policy through Beyond Oil.
HostB: Absolutely. He doesn’t need to run when he can spend and advocate from the sidelines.
